text: This next tape is an interview with Charlie Brown, the founder, editor, and publisher of Locust magazine. It took place in the early 1980s. Okay, the tapes were on, very informal, all that good stuff. We want to explore first of all how Locust got started. So how did you start it and how has it grown and evolved? Well I started Lucas in 1968. One of the main reasons I started was because I wanted to be able to learn how to write. I was as a full time fan and I could never think to write anybody a letter. So I decided if I had myself a deadline at that time was every two weeks, I would get some experience with writing, I'd be able to write letters and things like that. Well, it's 15 years later, I still can't write letters. I still put out the magazine. It's mainly involved from being about fandoms. It was done every other weekend. It was written on Friday, stenciled on Saturday, run-off and mailed on Sunday. There was always every other weekend with a gang of people in the house helping out, things like that. And it just kept thrilling. The one thing about a magazine is that if you keep putting out issues, you get more and more news. And gradually it changed more towards the professional side, mainly because that's where my interests were. And they were the people who responded more often than that. And eventually it grew to a point where I couldn't print it anymore. We went to professional printing and it's been growing ever since. And it's about the length of a short novel now. It started out as just one page. That's how it grew. Did you ever in your wildest dreams imagine that it would get as big circulation wise and production wise as it is? Well, no. It originally started out to only run for two years. uh the one of the other things that started out was this was a very uh an advertisement for the boston group you're getting for a world time i just wrote the original and the boston group put it out but that didn't work very well at the end of two years they didn't win the convention i think mainly because of locusts but then we discovered that we were uh being nominated for the Ugo. It seemed like it'd be interesting to run it right through the Boston Convention to try and win a Ugo, which we did, and after that we just never stopped. But I never imagined it would grow that much. Who did the name come from? The name came from various points, various things. A locus is the connecting points in a circle. And we considered ourselves connecting points to the science fiction professionals, fans and publishers. And the other thing was just from the old Spanish phrase of L.O.A., the letter of conference. that's why the letter column is so called LOCUS with a capital LLC Okay I didn't know that. You got something new You started out as a fan so you were obviously involved in a fan organization now how did you get interested in science fiction in the first place? Oh, I started reading Science II's, I was reading Astounding in the 40's and discovered fandom all around 1949 by finding a convention listed in the, one of the magazine they call Super Science Stories or something like that. I went to the 1950 convention. I was 12 years old and I went to this convention. Had a wonderful time and I met all these old men like Fred Cole and Lextardale Ray. They were old. Most of them were pushing thirty. And when you're twelve you don't think anybody's ever going to reach thirty. That's really up there and now it's frightening because I see all these people and the considered the same age pretty much, but that was how I discovered fandom, and I put out my first fantasy in about 1951, dropped out again when I was in college, things like that. I actually went back to it, late 50s. Next. How has fandom changed since those days? Well, there were women around, that helped. 1950 there were all these temporary 13 year old kids and that was about it. I was talking to Harlan Ellison today, he just said, the one thing, he just came back from Australia, he was guest with my free and French. You were on Locust Poll, the results lately seem to be showing that science fiction fans, at least the ones that answer polls, are getting older. does this indicate some kind of trend, do you think, in the people that read science fiction? Uh, I don't know. Our audience is always gotten older, mainly because the audience has stayed with us. About 80% of the people who read Locust in 1968 still read Locust. Which, of course, keeps raising the ages. where some new people, but not that many. One of the changes, of course, is in the magazine. The magazine is no longer aimed at teenage fans. It's aimed at the professionals. Of course, you need to attract the older professionals. I think there are probably no more than two or three professionals were not a people out of this movie. Oh. I don't know what you mean by a sense of responsibility. I'm doing for a living what I used to do for nothing. That's about it. I spent 15 years in Electrical Engineering. Designing Power Plants and things like that. I was a full time engineer up until uh six or seven years ago. So you finally got the uh the wherewithal that it takes to to jump out and just do this for uh full time then? Well we never done it full time, what happened was uh There was a, uh... Uh... A strong... There was a break in the engineering field by 1975. And I got laid off for the first time in my life. And I figured while I was waiting for the field to pick up again, I would try writing for the year. And so I did. I wrote... Oh, I wrote mostly non-fiction articles for magazines. I had to focus on the side and try to, you know, build it up as much as possible. And eventually I discovered I didn't even have to go back to work. Every once in a while I get a call for an engineering job, I feel very good about that but I have no intention to ever go back to it. Have you ever had any aspirations or tried to write science fiction? Not fiction. No. I've never had any interest in writing fiction. I've written a lot of nonfiction. I've written lots of technical books, but that's about it. Now that you edit LOCUS full time and it is a science fiction magazine, do you get to actually read science fiction very much? Oh yeah! I've read- uh, probably I've read half of the novels that are coming here out next tour. I read a lot of science fiction. I read a lot more mysteries but I read a lot of science fiction too. Yeah it doesn't really bother me at all. In fact it helped. I assume you're talking about Science Fishing Chronicle on Angli's Border, as soon as he started my speculation has gone way up. And he's interested in more people in the field. K. What, I assume that you still get a kick out of producing locusts. There's something that just makes you want to keep doing it, besides that it makes your living right now? Oh sure. I was looking at the blue lines for the new issue today and it's very exciting. The first time you see it come together and you see all the photographs together and all the stories in one place instead of pieces. And you've still got a real thrill when you I'll get my final copy tomorrow. I'll be down at the printer at 8.30 in the morning, watching the came run off. I'll pull out a copy myself and staple it together and then I'll have another copy. In your editorial, you generally acknowledge the help of people that help mail it or collate it or whatever. could you give us kind of a typical day where that takes place? It sounds like you have a big party and put locusts together and get it out. Oh, yeah, we do have a party. The people come over to toll the locusts. Well, it's not toll the locusts. It's nailing them. And we get the issue back from the printer in the afternoon, and one or two people may show up and help us put stamps on first-class copies. And then a larger crowd comes in the evening. and you see, everybody gets to eat dinner and sits around and drinks, and puts out, you know the uh, put all the labels on our face and put them in alphabetical order, and chronological order by zip code and they're sacked up and usually we finish by about 10-30 or 11, everybody sits around and talks about science fiction here. very few of the people which you would all fans. They're almost all writers. In fact, he had a contest last year for best first novel by a Locust co-leader. And he did have three nominees. And as far as I can tell, probably about 90% of the Locust co-leaders have written at least one novel. Do you have any... Not a fan gathering, much professional. Do you have any plans for Locust, things you'd like to do in the future, expand it, new areas, whatever? Actually, I'd like to do the opposite. I do not want to expand the magazine at all. It will expand anyway, it always does. But I have no interest in doing a bigger magazine. In fact, I find the magazine too big now and circulation too large. I really want to do a magazine for a limited number of people, where I can do it all myself at home. I'm very frightened about getting to the point where I need a large staff and an office and things like that. Everything's done at home right now. Some of the changes are always forced on us because there's more news that we feel we have to cover. As you've probably noticed, we're doing a lot more international coverage lately, covering the Soviet Union and European Conventions, and we've had some articles on Chinese science fiction. And I'm off to China next week for a tour, and I'll be at the University of Shanghai Discussion Center in fiction there. Locus has won countless awards. Does one become blasé about these awards? Two, Three, Four, Five, Six, Seven. Seven is almost countless. Do you get blasé about that, oh it's just another award? ...I don't know what you're doing in college, but I don't get tired of winning that. It's a lot of fun. There's been complaints, but they don't bother you too much. I solved the problems with complaints that Send Rachel up to pick them up every year. But I won't say anything, as long as people vote to Lowecist, I'll gladly accept to you, though. It's well deserved. I don't think anybody realistically, other than competitors, are gonna complain. No, I think it's more of a team effort than it was before. I could not put it out without people helping. And they appreciate that, too. The one change that will be happening with Locust, unfortunately, is the one that seems to happen every year, which is the price goes down. One of the things we do is, of course, we all need that. Pages when we raise the price. But the problem with all presses is that they're expensive to do. The engineer asked me to ask you when we were talking about fandom a while ago if you have any favorite fandom stories that you could relate to, something that's funny or whatever that sticks in your mind from those days? Oh, I have thousands of them, but I don't know what, you know, what's appropriate because most of them are tied in to the fandom of 1950s. My kind of period was, uh, all about 1950 to 56. Uh, and, uh, I don't know, uh, you know, knowing Harley Allison when he was 15, and, uh, still my buddy was 15, we were all, uh, in this together then. What I find interesting is that, uh, I've known these people now for more than 30 years, more than I've known my family. Oh no. I've been in closer contact with the flying fiction world in 1950 than I had with my relatives. Funny stories? I dunno. No, I can't really think of a funny story. okay gave us two years old and and and they usually throw them out. For years, they collected all these really far out letters, waiting to publish them on a final issue, but it doesn't look like there will be a final issue of Locust. So there's no reason to keeping them around anymore. We don't get that much mail on Locusts. It's mostly information and complaints, but basically, Especially straight information. Very few letters of praise, except for our 15th anniversary, it actually wrote to all of the people who were subscribers and originators. Almost all of them were professional writers. And it was very nice getting back the first letter from Robert Heinlein and the second letter from Isaac Rastanov and people like that. to all our fans and really appreciate what we're doing. I'll give you a tidbit, from the back of the current issues focus, but the next issue focus, For those interested, Robert Heinlein just finished a new novel and turned it in, and passed the novel. And that will do out for, probably, next spring. Stop right, sir. You must have an interesting pipeline to the publishers. It seems to me I've heard apocryphal stories that authors said that they read about their new book being published in Locust. Well, it's not apocryphal. That happens fairly often. Yeah. How is that arrangement? It's a material before they're sent out to publishers to the authors. Uh, it's just that we're in close contact with all the publishers. ok um we will take the show and cut it up and we'll probably do the taping in September and we'll send you a copy of it ok so we do appreciate getting to talk to you ok ok just a second ok ok yeah listen thanks a lot enjoy the port Thank you.
